description: App installs but you can not do anything with it because to sync an online calendar service you need to submit an email address to get a verification code. You will never receive the verification code no matter how many times you try or request a resend. And no, the verification code did not go to my email spam or junk folder. I waited for the code for a long time. Never arrived... thus useless.
guys, remember this is a paid app from the developer. so I urge people who download this app to read the terms and visit their web-page
summary: this is a paid app after 14days of trial

description:
Desktop calendar apps are one of the cornerstones of my time management and planning process: without a good calendar app, I would be severely hampered in all my working activities.

Calendar apps in the Linux scene are surprisingly underdeveloped compared to other OSs: stuff that I was taking for granted on Apple Calendar (when I still had a Mac) are apparently borderline impossible on Linux.

Simply put, if like me you are looking for a reliable, stand-alone, calendar app that can support multiple protocols (Google and Office 365 in my case), then Morgen is the only SW that can answer your needs.

Lightning? Not stand-alone. California? Development has stuck. Gnome calendar? Requires installing Evolution for exchange support and prone to bugs (and I am talking of stuff like the app crashing for months when viewing 2021 events, or wrong time zone on ICS invitations).

If you are in a position similar to mine, then Morgen is the only available choice: for the fact of being there it gets the 5 stars.

Now, there are a few annoying things:

1) The app is an evolution of the research-oriented MineTime, but oddly enough it lacks some of the features of its progenitors (such as natural text input). Until a months ago or so, it was also a bit less stable and less usable. Thankfully, development is going strong and the app is improving a lot.

2) More annoyingly, the app is not free, and the pricing scheme has changed w.r.t. the MineTime one. In particular, educational licenses used to be free, but this is no longer the case.

3) The fact that MineTime was about to be replaced by a new, more commercially oriented, app was poorly communicated at the time. I kind of knew that was coming (a company needs to sustain itself), but still it took me a while to digest this.

That said, if you willing to pay the monthly price, this is a great app about to become even better.
summary: The only reliable, stand-alone, multi-protocol calendar app on Linux

description: I'm sorry, but I ain't paying for no calendar with so many free alternatives.
Finally a calendar app that looks good on Linux
By far the best calendar app available, I even use it on my Windows machine as it keeps everything in sync. By far the most useful app ever
I didn't even try any futher. Is a shame how Ubuntu and Linux is more and more becoming a pool of bloat and adware.
summary: Requires your personal email address to start

description: I'm using Fantastical and Busycal3 but I always missed this tiny app on my Ubuntu laptop. It doesn't have many functions but simply enough to check my tasks.

I recomed to deal with Exchange calendars.
Waiting for new features.
I haven't found a better calendar for Linux. Have all you need and doesn't break like the GNOME one.
Good UI, best alternative

Calendar itself looks pretty nice, but you can't use this app without creating an account on the Morgen site so they can track, harvest, and sell your data.

This app shouldn't even be listed in the store.
summary: Another way to harvest your data

description:
Custom multi-day scheduling has issues..
Do a custom 2 day repeat with an end time in the same week and it populates the entire calendar for every two days from the starting day ignoring the end date.

Default all day scheduling should come up as blank not blocked.
No option to set default calendar out of 2 or more Calendars under 1 account.

Location popup is blink and you miss it
CALDAV imports/syncs only Appointment Calendars; No Task Lists (only) will be synced. Useless when there are so many Calendars outside. Tasks is the magic.

forces you to link to one of the main calendar providers such as google, microsoft, or apple.
asks for your login credentials and asks for you to trust them with the credentials. what a joke.
If i wanted to use the big players, I would have used them already, i don't need to pay money so you can steal my data.
This works great for seeing my work and personal calendars at once. I've been using it as a replacement to Sunsama for daily planning.

I've tried so many different calendars on Linux and if you need anything that consolidates mulitple calendars and consistently works, this is app is the one. The UI is super user friendly and aside from some minor nice to have features on their roadmap, it does everything I need. 

I know many in the Linux community refuse to pay for services but I say this one is worth it. And to be fair, you only have to pay the subscription if you have more than one calendar to sync.

They have been continoulsy making improvements and in my mind that is so refreshing considering so many of my beloved apps have have gone dormant.
Best calendar app i've used so far
Datenachutz-technisch indiskutabel, wenn ich meine Daten über den Anbieter übertragen lassen muss.
Man muss sich anmelden, um es nutzen zu koennen
nicht zu empfehlen
Me gusta porque es una gran pagina

Au premier démarrage de l'application on vous demande pour poursuivre d'ouvrir un compte pour la synchronisation des données sur le site de la compagnie et éventuellement entrer en contact avec vous, etc 
Je désinstalle
summary: Il faut ouvrir un compte de synchronisation
